title: How to Remove Fluid in Ears

steps.title: Clean your ears out with hydrogen peroxide.
steps.content: Clean your ears out with hydrogen peroxide. Fill half of an ear dropper with hydrogen peroxide. Turn your head so that the affected ear is on top. Drop the hydrogen peroxide into the ear. Once the crackling noise stops (usually within 5 minutes), tilt your head so that your affected ear faces down. Tug on the earlobe to help the ear drain. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Apply ear drying drops to your ears.
steps.content: Apply ear drying drops to your ears. You can buy these over-the-counter at pharmacies and grocery stores. The solution will usually come with an ear dropper, but they are typically available for purchase at pharmacies if not. Alternatively, you can make your own drying drops with equal parts white vinegar and isopropyl alcohol. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Blow your ear with a hairdryer.
steps.content: Blow your ear with a hairdryer. Turn the hairdryer onto its lowest heat and fan setting. Set the blow-dryer about 6 inches (15 cm) from your ear. Let the cool air blow into your ear. The air can help dry up some of the fluid that is caught in the ear. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Dry your outer ears with a towel after swimming and showering.
steps.content: Dry your outer ears with a towel after swimming and showering. Don’t put the towel inside of your ear. [5] X Expert Source Payam Daneshrad, MD Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 30 September 2020. Just wipe off the water on the outside to prevent more fluid from building up in your ears. [6] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source

steps.title: Avoid using cotton swabs or tissues in your ears.
steps.content: Avoid using cotton swabs or tissues in your ears. [7] X Expert Source Payam Daneshrad, MD Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 30 September 2020. These can irritate and scratch your ears, increasing your chances of getting an infection. Instead, if you can’t dislodge the water on your own, see a doctor for help. [8] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source

steps.title: Tug the outside of your ear while tilting your head.
steps.content: Tug the outside of your ear while tilting your head. Point your affected ear down to the ground. Tug on your earlobe and the outer cartilage in different directions to open up your ear. You may feel the fluid drain out. Repeat if needed on the other ear. [9] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source This is a good way to get rid of water after swimming or a shower.

steps.title: Create a vacuum with your hand to release the fluid.
steps.content: Create a vacuum with your hand to release the fluid. Place the palm of your hand tightly over your ear. Press down a few times before removing your hand. Tilt your ear down so that the water can drain out. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Relieve the pressure with a gentle Valsalva maneuver.
steps.content: Relieve the pressure with a gentle Valsalva maneuver. Take a breath and hold it. Plug your nose with 2 fingers, and force air up the Eustachian tubes in your ears by blowing. You should feel a pop if it works. Tilt your head downward, with the affected ear facing toward the ground to let the fluid drain out. [11] X Research source Do not do this if you think you have an ear infection. Be gentle as you blow. If you blow too hard, you may cause a nosebleed.

steps.title: Pinch your nose and yawn to force the fluid down your throat.
steps.content: Pinch your nose and yawn to force the fluid down your throat. Hold your nostrils closed with your fingers. Take a few deep yawns in a row. This may cause the fluid to slide back down your throat, removing it from your ears. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Lie down with your affected ear turned downward.
steps.content: Lie down with your affected ear turned downward. Rest on your side, with the affected ear down against a towel, pillow, or cloth. After a few minutes, the ear may start to drain. You can even take a nap or try this overnight as you sleep.

steps.title: Chew on gum or food.
steps.content: Chew on gum or food. Chewing often opens up the Eustachian tubes. Tilt your head as you chew to encourage fluid to drain from your ears. If you don’t have any gum or food on you, try just pretending to chew. [13] X Research source You can also try sucking on a hard candy to get the same effect.

steps.title: Loosen the fluid with steam treatment.
steps.content: Loosen the fluid with steam treatment. Sometimes, a long, hot shower is enough to loosen the fluid in your ear. However, if not, a simple steam treatment may thin the fluid, making it easier to drain. Pour hot water into a bowl. Lean over the bowl and drape a towel over your head. Inhale the steam for 5-10 minutes. Then tilt your affected ear to the side to let the fluid drain out. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Take a decongestant if you have a sinus infection or cold.
steps.content: Take a decongestant if you have a sinus infection or cold. The decongestant will allow your ears to drain naturally. Take the medication according to the instructions on the label. You can use an over-the-counter decongestant, such as Sudafed or Afrin, in pill or spray form. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Visit your doctor if your ears don’t clear up after 3-4 days.
steps.content: Visit your doctor if your ears don’t clear up after 3-4 days. [20] X Expert Source Payam Daneshrad, MD Board Certified Otolaryngologist Expert Interview. 30 September 2020. Your doctor may prescribe a cortisone pill, such as Prednisone or Medrol. Take this medication according to your doctor’s instructions. Your ears will usually clear up after 3-4 days. [21] X Research source This pill will decrease inflammation in your Eustachian Tubes in your ears so that fluid can drain naturally.

steps.title: Take antibiotics as prescribed by your doctor.
steps.content: Take antibiotics as prescribed by your doctor. Antibiotics are especially important for children, although adults may use them too. The antibiotics will treat any current infection and prevent new ones from developing. [22] X Trustworthy Source MedlinePlus Collection of medical information sourced from the US National Library of Medicine Go to source

steps.title: Have a doctor check for growths if fluid appears in 1 ear without a cold.
steps.content: Have a doctor check for growths if fluid appears in 1 ear without a cold. If you suddenly have unexplained fluid in only 1 of your ears, it can be a symptom of a growth, such as a benign tumor or cancer. Ask your doctor for a referral to an Ear, Nose, and Throat (ENT) doctor. The ENT will perform a cancer screening. [23] X Research source The ENT will begin with a visual examination of your ear and blood tests. If they think you have a growth in your ear, they will give you a local anesthetic and take a sample of the tissue for testing. MRI scans may also be used. [24] X Trustworthy Source Cancer Research UK U.K.-based cancer research and advocacy charity Go to source

steps.title: Opt for surgery if the fluid can't be removed any other way.
steps.content: Opt for surgery if the fluid can't be removed any other way. Since it can take a while for the ear to drain completely, they may place a tube in your ear. When your ears have healed, your doctor will remove the tube at their office. They will also follow up with you occasionally to make sure your ears are in good condition after the surgery. [25] X Research source Children may need the tubes in their ears for between 4 and 6 months. Adults may only need the tubes for 4-6 weeks. The first surgery will require anesthesia at a hospital as an outpatient procedure. Tubes often fall out on their own, or they can be removed without the use of anesthesia at your doctor's office.
